title: Oak Forest
question_text:
The proportion of red oak trees on the west-facing slope of a 200 acre forest is known to be pw=0.82 . The east-facing slope has known proportion of pe=0.73 . The numbers of trees per acre in this densely packed forest is 550 . A research team tags a random sample of 56 trees from the west-facing slope and an additional random sample of 40 trees from the east-facing slope.
What is the probability that the difference between the proportion of red oaks in the west and east samples, ˆ p w− ˆ p e , is more than 25% ?

choices.text: The answer cannot be computed because the population distribution of the difference between the proportion of west and east facing slope red oaks is unknown.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect.

The standard deviation was incorrectly computed using the square root of the difference in variances. Remember that even though we are considering a difference in sample proportions, the standard deviation of the sampling distribution will be the square root the the sum of the variances.

Choice 'B' is incorrect.

The standard deviation was incorrectly computed using the pooled proportion. Pooling is used in hypothesis testing when we are building a model under the assumption that the proportions are equal. That is not the case here where we know the population proportion of red oaks on the west-facing and east-facing slopes are different.

Choice 'D' is incorrect.

The Normal probability calculations were likely performed with variance instead of standard deviation. The incorrect standardized
z
-score was large enough to make a difference in proportion of oak tress on the west and east coast nearly impossible.

Choice 'E' is incorrect.

Because the Large Counts Condition is satisfied (see above), the sampling distribution of the difference in proportion of red oaks on the west slope and east slope is approximately Normal even if the population distribution is unknown.
